Owings and Shrider Stage Pitchers'
Duel. Last Game Marked by
Loose Fielding.

In two contests that had an important bearing on the State baseball championship the Hopkins
nine had to be contented with an
even break, losing a hard fought
contest to Maryland by a 2-0 score
and then reversing the count on
St. John's in the second game. In
spite of the final outcome the
State game proved the big attraction of the day. Bobby Owings,
on the mound for the Black and
Blue, and Schrider for the College
Parkers, fought out the closest
twirlers' duel that,has been seen
on Homewood Field- this year.
The second game, while close at
all times, was - nevertheless all
Hopkins after the second inning.
FOr the first four- innings of the
initial game a few had breaks and
errors kept Bobby Owings in continued hot water..In each of the
first two innings State,men got on
the bases, but could not furnish
the punch to score. However, in
the third, three singles brought
over the run that spelt final defeat for the Black and Blue. In
the fourth frame Maryland scored
its second and final tally and
sewed up the game. From then
on it was a real pitchers' battle
with Hopkins having a slight
edge.
The first real attempt to stave
off defeat came in the seventh,
when Rich, who seemed able to
solve Schrider's delivery with
ease, singled and went to third,
when Knecht did the same. However, two were down and Ben
Thomas couldn't furnish the
needed bingle. In the eighth
came Hopkins' best chance to
win the game. Wilson was passed,
but Owings struck out and Buck
Grace was robbed of a hit' when
his hard-line drive was snared by
Eddie Semler. Besley then slipped
up on Reifschneider's grounder
and threw wild to first. Hayter
was hit, but Sharretts, after fouling a half-dozen times, was
thrown out at first.
In the second game the Black
and Blue came back and trounced
the. Annapolitans •by a score of
6-4. Andy Knecht hurled a good
game, but was not supported as
well as was Owings in the initial
encounter. The second inning
really decided the game when
Hopkins put over four tallies.
Knecht reached first on an error
by Cashell, Wilson singled over
second and Grace walked. Another one-base hit by Reifschneider and a smashing triple by Marran brought in a quartet of tallies.
In the second the Hopkins team
Went up in the air in the field and
St. John's scored two runs without a hit. Two passes, two passed
balls and an error by Reifschneider, coupled with Sharrets' indifContinzted on page 4, col. 4.

The matter of the disagreement year before last as to the eligibility of players (the argument which ended in a severance of relations) should remain a closed affair. The question of regulations has
been settled by the officials of the two institutions. It remains to us
to turn out strong in every Hopkins-Maryland contest and put the
Black and Blue where it belongs at the top of the ladder.

EXTRA ISSUES
In recognition of the twenty-fifth birthday of the News-Letter
the staff Will endeavor to put out an extra issue. This edition will
contain, for the most part, a number of special articles on the University twenty-five years ago and now.
A Class Day issue will also be published following the examinations.

ZIONIST SOCIETY ELECTS NEW
OFFICERS

At an election of officers held last
Friday afternoon by the Zionist Society, the following men were
chosen:
President — Jacob Finesinger,
'24.
Vice-President — Isidore Terl tsky, '23.
Secretary—Samuel S. Eisenberg,
'23.
Financial Secretary—Sidney Esterson, '24.
The following executive committee was elected at the same time:
I. Terlitsky, chairman; S. Eisenberg, I. Esterson, P. Smoller, D.
Shapiro, and I. Finesinger, ex-officio. M. Miller, E. Aaronson and
S. Eisenberg were elected to the
entertainment committee.

Owings and Shrider Stage Pitchers'
Duel. Last Game Marked by
Loose Fielding.

In two contests that had an important bearing on the State baseball championship the Hopkins
nine had to be contented with an
even break, losing a hard fought
contest to Maryland by a 2-0 score
and then reversing the count on
St. John's in the second game. In
spite of the final outcome the
State game proved the big attraction of the day. Bobby Owings,
on the mound for the Black and
Blue, and Schrider for the College
Parkers, fought out the closest
twirlers' duel that,has been seen
on Homewood Field- this year.
The second game, while close at
all times, was - nevertheless all
Hopkins after the second inning.
FOr the first four- innings of the
initial game a few had breaks and
errors kept Bobby Owings in continued hot water..In each of the
first two innings State,men got on
the bases, but could not furnish
the punch to score. However, in
the third, three singles brought
over the run that spelt final defeat for the Black and Blue. In
the fourth frame Maryland scored
its second and final tally and
sewed up the game. From then
on it was a real pitchers' battle
with Hopkins having a slight
edge.
The first real attempt to stave
off defeat came in the seventh,
when Rich, who seemed able to
solve Schrider's delivery with
ease, singled and went to third,
when Knecht did the same. However, two were down and Ben
Thomas couldn't furnish the
needed bingle. In the eighth
came Hopkins' best chance to
win the game. Wilson was passed,
but Owings struck out and Buck
Grace was robbed of a hit' when
his hard-line drive was snared by
Eddie Semler. Besley then slipped
up on Reifschneider's grounder
and threw wild to first. Hayter
was hit, but Sharretts, after fouling a half-dozen times, was
thrown out at first.
In the second game the Black
and Blue came back and trounced
the. Annapolitans •by a score of
6-4. Andy Knecht hurled a good
game, but was not supported as
well as was Owings in the initial
encounter. The second inning
really decided the game when
Hopkins put over four tallies.
Knecht reached first on an error
by Cashell, Wilson singled over
second and Grace walked. Another one-base hit by Reifschneider and a smashing triple by Marran brought in a quartet of tallies.
In the second the Hopkins team
Went up in the air in the field and
St. John's scored two runs without a hit. Two passes, two passed
balls and an error by Reifschneider, coupled with Sharrets' indifContinzted on page 4, col. 4.

EXTRA ISSUES
In recognition of the twenty-fifth birthday of the News-Letter
the staff Will endeavor to put out an extra issue. This edition will
contain, for the most part, a number of special articles on the University twenty-five years ago and now.
A Class Day issue will also be published following the examinations.

'24.

'23.

Shapiro, and I. Finesinger, ex-officio. M. Miller, E. Aaronson and
S. Eisenberg were elected to the
entertainment committee.
